definition.formal: Free aortic rupture refers to the complete disruption of the aortic wall with hemorrhage into the peritoneal cavity or unrestricted mediastinal/pleural space, resulting in rapid exsanguination and cardiovascular collapse.
definition.clinical: Catastrophic uncontained aortic bleeding causing immediate hemodynamic instability with mortality approaching 90% without immediate intervention.

core_concepts.explanation: Complete transmural aortic wall disruption allows unrestricted hemorrhage. The peritoneal cavity offers no tamponade, unlike retroperitoneal rupture. Rapid blood loss causes immediate shock. Mortality is directly proportional to time from rupture to aortic control.
core_concepts.clinical_significance: Unlike contained rupture, there is no time for stabilization - immediate OR transport is the only chance for survival.

core_concepts.explanation: Classic triad of abdominal pain, pulsatile mass, and hypotension is rarely complete because patients lose consciousness rapidly. More commonly presents as sudden cardiovascular collapse. Abdominal distension develops quickly from hemoperitoneum.
core_concepts.clinical_significance: High index of suspicion in any elderly patient with sudden hemodynamic collapse. Time to OR, not diagnostic imaging, determines survival.

core_concepts.explanation: Contained rupture is tamponaded by retroperitoneal tissues, allowing time for diagnosis and treatment. Free rupture has no containment. Intraperitoneal rupture (free rupture) carries much higher mortality than retroperitoneal (often contained) rupture.
core_concepts.clinical_significance: Contained rupture patients may be awake and talking; free rupture patients are obtunded or in arrest. Treatment is dramatically different.

core_concepts.explanation: Massive transfusion protocol activation is immediate. Balanced resuscitation with 1:1:1 PRBCs:FFP:platelets. Limit crystalloid. Goal is restoration of adequate perfusion without increasing blood pressure excessively before aortic control.
core_concepts.clinical_significance: Aggressive crystalloid resuscitation worsens dilutional coagulopathy and may pop the clot in partially contained ruptures.

core_concepts.explanation: Supraceliac aortic control through left crus is fastest approach. May consider aortic balloon occlusion via femoral access (REBOA) as temporizing measure. Proximal control before entering hematoma is essential. Cell saver use if available.
core_concepts.clinical_significance: Entering the hematoma before proximal control leads to uncontrollable hemorrhage and death. The surgeon's primary goal is proximal control.

signs_and_symptoms: Mottled skin and poor peripheral perfusion
physical_examination: Distended abdomen (if survivable time to examine)

differential_diagnosis.distinguishing_features: ECG changes, no abdominal distension, different pain pattern
Patient hemodynamically responsive to resuscitation, may stabilize
Right heart strain pattern, no abdominal findings
May have mediastinal hematoma, tearing pain between shoulders

immediate_management: Immediate OR notification (do not wait for diagnostic studies)
REBOA consideration if trained and equipped
Direct transport to OR (bypass CT scanner)

key_steps: Supraceliac aortic control through left crus of diaphragm
Medial visceral rotation to expose aorta
Evacuate hematoma after proximal control achieved
Infrarenal clamp placement if anatomy permits
Open repair with tube or bifurcated graft

treatment.endovascular_options: EVAR for free rupture is controversial and rarely feasible. Most patients are too unstable for imaging and device deployment. May be considered in highly selected cases with experienced team and hybrid OR.

prognostic_factors: Time from collapse to aortic control
Volume of blood loss before control

learning_objectives: Differentiate free rupture from contained rupture presentation and prognosis
Describe immediate resuscitation priorities in free AAA rupture
Explain rationale for permissive hypotension and limiting crystalloid
Describe technique for achieving supraceliac aortic control
Identify factors associated with survival in free AAA rupture
key_takeaways: Free rupture has 80-90% mortality - time is the critical variable
DO NOT image patients in extremis - go directly to OR
Proximal aortic control BEFORE entering hematoma saves lives
Balanced resuscitation with blood products, not crystalloid
Supraceliac control through left crus is the fastest approach
